documents.document: Very few diaspora Mexicans voted, just 98,470, though this double the turnout from 2012. Politicians don’t campaign for the votes of migrants but for migrants’ perceived influence over the votes of relatives back home. See my analysis for @TheWilsonCenter https://t.co/eTNGWlpysD

AMLO campaigned in 8 US cities even though this is technically against Mexican election law. This was a big change in campaign strategy from 2006 when he refused to go to the US at all. He was helped by electoral reforms that eased registration abroad.

But diaspora Mexicans were never a reliable base for the PAN given their socioeconomic diversity. Having failed to halt corruption and violence after two terms in office, the party had squandered much of its legacy as the party of democratic change among Mexicans abroad.

For 2 decades, the default opposition party for Mexicans abroad (mostly US) was the PAN, beginning with Fox, who had widespread diaspora support. In 2012, Vázquez Mota won the largest vote share in the diaspora despite getting the smallest vote share overall.

The PRI, being in power for 7 decades, produced 7 decades of emigrants who blamed the party for the conditions under which they left. Other Mexican parties compete for diaspora support by being the most viable alternative to the PRI.
The consistent trend across all elections is the disproportionate skew against the PRI. The Mexico diaspora vote isn’t pro-PAN or pro-AMLO. It is anti-PRI.

In past elections, diaspora Mexicans have voted disproportionately for the PAN candidates relative to domestic voters. This year, they voted disproportionately for AMLO. @MexicoInstitute https://t.co/DLjht9fkyH

How Mexico’s diaspora voted:
64.9% López Obrador (MORENA/PT/ES) 26.8% Anaya Cortés (PAN/PRD/MC) 4.7% Meade Kuribreña (PRI/PVEM/NA) 1.9% Rodríguez Calderón

@robocopnixon Yeah well extrapolating national political trends based on a single conversation at an Applebee’s is a pretty unique skill set.

Also for journalists: saying things like “ideology drives politics more than race” is not just a speculative question. It’s a research question political scientists have looked at for years. There is lots of evidence out there to inform your views. Do your homework, or ask.

Krauthammer never represented the Republican Party. His views and those of other ideologues within DC media circles never reflected the motivations of partisan base voters, who care little about ideological purity. But he had a platform because media people like that myth.

That any national political reporter can think that racial attitudes did not motivate political divides - under Obama! - speaks to the level of self delusion among political commentators who want to believe everyone is as polite and intellectually honest as they see themselves
https://t.co/b3nkmqa2MR
There is, on the other hand, plenty of evidence to the contrary. https://t.co/d9whlj9sHD https://t.co/HUWQPo3sAI

This is a common lament among political journalists with short memories, that US politics in the past was somehow nobler and driven by pure ideological differences rather than racial in-group prejudices. There isn’t any evidence of this.
